turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We'll hear argument next in No. 87-1485, Arthur Blanchard v. James Bergeron.
Mr. Rosen, you may proceed whenever you are ready.

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court:
The Blanchard police brutality case presents two issues.
The first is whether a contingent fee contract forms a cap on section 1988 reasonable fees, and the second is whether paraprofessional time should be included within the auspices of section 1988.
I came to this case after it had already been filed.
A fellow attorney became ill and asked me to take it over.
I reviewed it, decided that it had merit, and after that asked him what sort of fee arrangement he had.
He told me he had a 40 percent contingent fee contract with Mr. Blanchard, but that if I won, or the case was won, there would be fees under the Civil Rights Attorney's Fee Award Act.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Mr. Rosen, tell me how those two work together.
Does the attorney get both fees?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: No, sir.
I think you've got to then look at what is meant.
For example, I would say 99 percent of all negligence cases that are taken in the United States are taken when the client comes in, a contingent fee contract is accepted on that sort of basis.
But section 1988 applies to the end of the case, and is not a relationship with the client, it is the implementation of fees against a losing party who has violated a civil rights.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Well, I understand all that.
But I want to know what the, what the attorney gets out of the winning case.
Does he get both fees?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: I don't think so.
I think he gets a reasonable fee as determined by the court, after review of the Loadstar method.
Now--

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: So that the contingent fee then, arrangement, really means nothing?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: --It is in, for general purposes, I think, irrelevant as to the implementation of 1988 fees.

May it be a consideration for enhancement for the value of the vindication of a right, over and above what the court may think is a satisfactory fee on an hourly basis times hour... hourly amount, a fee, time number of hours, Loadstar.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Well, then you think the court would fix the reasonable fee loss the contingent fee?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: Justice Blackmun, I don't think that the contingent fee per se is a consideration.
I think it is irrelevant in the, in the implementation of 1988.

I do not think that it is, it is a relevant factor, because it is the private agreement between a client and an attorney, whereas the implementation of 1988 comes at the end after all of the work has been done and Congress, the Intent of Congress, as I understand it from the cases, are that this is part of the vindication of the civil right.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: I understand all that.
But I can also sense a lot of attorneys taking both fees.

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: If 1988 is implemented correctly, I do not think that both fees probably are necessary or probably should be taken.

I think then you may get into the possibility of consideration of windfall, but I don't think that's... I think it's a consideration but I think the reasonable fee as instituted, as required by 1988, is the primary consideration, and that primary consideration is Loadstar.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Well, I'm wondering really why, in a case that is subject to 1988, a contingent fee arrangement is at all necessary or indeed indicated.

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: I think the reason for that, Justice Blackmun, is this.
A client walks into an attorney's office and says, I have--

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: I know exactly how it happens.
You don't have to tell me that.
But I want to know where--

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: --He may not know... the attorney may not know what he has.
He may not be aware that it involves a civil right violation when someone comes into his office.
Therefore, if it involves a negligence type of situation, the standard agreement, as I say I think probably 99 percent or more--

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: --Well, that's a little high, after my old practice days anyway.

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: --And I think, sir, that the, that the standard before you even know what the investigation will show as to what kind of case you have, is a contingent fee contract.

Now, basically what the Fifth Circuit said to me was that, Mr. Rosen, you didn't take, you didn't adjust the contract, which was not mine to begin with, but you did not go back and adjust the contract to say, I'll take the higher of the 1988 or contingent fee or whatever it was that should be adjusted.
What the Fifth Circuit says, next time you'll know better.
That's precisely what they said in their opinion.
I just don't think that's the correct application of 1988.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Rosen, do you read the Fifth Circuit opinion as saying that the $4,000 attorney's fee is payable by the defendant over and above the $5,000 actual damages and the $5,000 punitive damages?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: Yes sir, Over, over and... yes.
It is a fee on top of the actual damage portion.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: So--

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: Otherwise it would be, it would certainly be a windfall to the defendant.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --Yes.
So the defendant will have to pay $14,000 under the Fifth Circuit's judgment?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: The defendant would have to pay $14,000... well, I hope that is what the Fifth Circuit said.
Mr. Chief Justice, I cannot tell from reading the Fifth Circuit opinion whether that is actually what they meant.
I would certainly hope that's what they meant, but they don't say that the defendants shall pay this additional amount, or that it shall come out of Mr. Blanchard's portion.
I certainly hope it's the former of those, and I think that clearly is the intent of this Court and the intent of Congress to do that.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: The District Court awarded you $7,500 in attorney's fees.

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And did you appeal from that?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: I appealed from that on two bases--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And those are the two that you raise here?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: --Well, the first in the appeal to the Fifth Circuit, the paraprofessional issue, was included within the whole attorney fee issue.
But the second part, which I did not bring to this Court, was the law court awarded me out of some $5,000 out-of-pocket expenses of my own on the case, they awarded me about $800.
The Fifth Circuit reimbursed me almost the whole $5,000 approximately, so I did not bring that issue to this Court.
The issue here involves the cap issue, and obviously I cannot win on the paraprofessional issue unless you reverse on the cap issue.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I ask you a question about... just following up really on Justice Blackmun's question... supposing you had not appealed, just received the $7,500 fee, and putting the costs to one side for a moment.
Is it your understanding that $4,000 of that $7,500 would have gone to the client and you would have kept $3,500?
Or would it have all gone to you, or all to the client?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: Justice Stevens, as a practical matter, I have received no fee at the present time.
So that in answer to your question, my understanding is that I would have received $7,500 from the defendant.
And the client would get the entire $10,000--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: --Which had been awarded, and I hope and I think that's the way the process should work.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Or if the client had paid you the... say they had paid the principal judgment right away while the fees were being debated, $10,000 would have been paid to the client, the client would have paid you $4,000 as the 40 percent contingent fees then if thereafter $7,500 was recovered $4,000 would go to the client and $3,500 would go to you.

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: I think that's the way the system should work.

That's, that's my opinion, because certainly it would be hoped, under the intent of Congress, under the civil rights statute, what if a judge or a jury declares that Mr. Blanchard in this case was damaged to the degree of $5,000 compensatory and $5,000 punitive damages, it seems to me when you have the Civil Rights Attorney's Fee Award Act, that the reasonable compensation of the attorney should be based on that, and the person who has had his rights damaged should then get whatever the judge or jury has awarded.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, what would happen if an attorney spent just a small number of hours on a case and received a huge award, and he had a contingent fee contract?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: Justice Kennedy, you mean a huge award under the contingent fee?

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: Under the contingent fee--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And, and suppose that we'd all stipulate that a reasonable fee would be $20,000 but his contingent fee was $100,000, what happens then?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: --I think then you get into the area of whether or not the vindication of the particular right was worthy of an enhancement and at that period of time, at that time, then it is a question of looking at what is the relationship and what does the contract call for.
It may well--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well suppose the, suppose the trial court said a reasonable fee here is $20,000, but the judgment was huge, and under the contingent fee contract the fee award under the contingent contract was $100,000?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: --It may well be that a reasonable fee then would be $20,000, in your example, $20,000.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: It is.
But does the attorney get to keep the $100,000 enforcing his contract against the client?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: I don't think that the attorney keeps the $100,000, except--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: You mean the contingency fee contract is just, is just invalidated?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: --Except to the degree for 1988 purposes, except to the degree of the value of the enhancement of the right, of the enforcement of the right--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You think 1988 was intended to reduce the contractual entitlement of the lawyer?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: --I think--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I mean, here you have a lawyer who struck a deal for, you know, to get $100,000, and you're telling me 1988 was meant to somehow interfere with that contractual agreement?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: --I think there are two different issues.
I think the issue of the private contractual relationship between the attorney and client is one controlled by private law of contract and state law.
I think the 1988 issue... and that comes into play as I've mentioned at the very beginning of the relationship.
At the end, 1988 comes into play at the end.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That's fine.
But which one trumps?
Why doesn't he get $100,000?
That's all that I don't understand.
Why doesn't he--

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: Clearly, from the basis of a civil right litigation, 1988 does, under the supremacy clause of the Constitution.
And this Court basically has said that in--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --Well, the supremacy clause doesn't have anything to do with a private contract.

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: --No, sir.
It has nothing to do with a private contract.
For example, suppose in the court's wisdom I got $1 worth of fee.
Would I feel justified in the hours and time put in to say to Mr. Blanchard, I think under state law I will enforce this contract for $4,000?
I think I would be justified.
Now--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Supposing that a client walk into your office with something that you, being a knowledgable lawyer, know is a civil rights case, and that there will therefore be an award of attorney's fees if you win, and you tell the client, I think we can get a judgment for $100,000 here and if we do I think the court probably is going to award another $50,000 as attorney's fees.
My arrangement with you is, I'm going to take half of whatever the court awards, both as damages and as attorney's fees.
So if we get $100,000 damages and $50,000 attorney's fees I will get $75,000 and you will get $75,000.
Do you think that is a permissible arrangement?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: --I think it is permissible.
I think that the question is always in the civil rights area the reasonable fee under 1988.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, do you--

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: Then the question--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --Supposing that you're an attorney, you've negotiated that sort of an arrangement, you come to the court and you say, this is what I want the judgment entered for.
In other words, is the court going to uphold that kind of a fee arrangement?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: --Mr. Chief Justice, there are various fee arrangements--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, I've given you one fee arrangement.
Will you answer my question?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: --The court may uphold that fee arrangement if they find it reasonable.
Yes sir.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, what factors would they take into consideration in deciding whether it was reasonable or not?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: I think the fact of time spent on the case, of market rate of billing hours, I think the degree of success in the vindication of the civil right.
Somebody can certainly handle a case quicker or achieve a result quicker than someone else, but that still does not mean that a fee is reduced.
So there are a number of factors I think are very valid.
But simply to--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Rosen, the hypothesis is that after taking into all, account all of those factors the judge concludes that $50,000 is a reasonable fee.
Then the question is if you have a contractual right to another $25,000 can you enforce the contract?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: --I would have to say that, if the court said a reasonable fee was $50,000, then under that civil... if the only issue was the civil rights case--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: --Then I think that $50,000 must be accepted as the reasonable fee.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And that a private contractual arrangement in the civil rights area for a higher fee would be unenforceable as a matter of federal law.

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: Unless there was an enhancement factor that the court looked at.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No, no.
All these enhancement factors have been taken into account in determining the court-awarded reasonable fee of $50,000.
You're saying, as I understand you, that as a matter of federal law precludes an additional fee, even though the parties had contracted for it.

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: I think in the civil rights area I have to argue that is, that is the correct fee, if the court says it is the correct fee.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The state court too?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: I'm not sure that applies to the state court too, if there is a state, if there is a state issue involved in it.
For example, the court, a couple of recent cases that, Justice Marshall, clearly have said that when it comes to a civil rights case, 1983--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: No, that's not my point.
My point is you get the $75,000 from the federal side, and you'd come back to the client and say, I also have one with you for $40,000.
Does the state court enforce that $40,000 one?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: --I think under the rulings of this Court in the supremacy area that the federal civil rights acts are supreme to that issue also.
I'm not quite sure I understand the question, but I--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You said in the contract, if I win, if I win I will give you 40 percent of what I make.
And not... the one two words that are not in that contract are civil rights.
Would that be enforceable after you collect the federal money?
Yes or no.

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: --I do not believe it would be enforceable if the federal court had determined a reasonable fee.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And the state court couldn't enforce a state contract?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: The state court could enforce a state contract were it not for the holdings of this Court in the area of supremacy of the civil rights statute.
Now, that my be talking against myself, against my brother lawyers, but I think a reasonable fee is a reasonable fee.
The question is, have I, or what is a reasonable fee for the work performed?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, you can get disputes as to what's reasonable fee.
I've seen it run as high as 70 percent, which I didn't think was reasonable, but I found people did think it was.

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: Well, it's clear that both in state and federal law, clear certainly in Louisiana that cases go back to, I think, 1934--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I'm talking about Louisiana.

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: --That if I took a 70 percent contingent fee contract the courts are going to review it, because the courts have final jurisdiction to review attorney's fees.
If I took $5,000 an hour as a fee, contract, even if submitted to by the client, he later objected, that is going to be subject to court jurisdiction to review.
So it is going to be a subject which is always, the final arbiter of it is going to be the courts, no matter what court it is.
I would like to talk briefly... one other question, one other issue on the, on the cap, and that is, we have been talking about fees and money and proportions.
But we are really talking there about monetary awards, and certainly it has been shown and held by many courts that the monetary award is not the only factor.
If monetary award were the only factor, then this would be nothing more than a negligence case.
The other factors are the vindication of a right.
And that is, as I read the cases, the principal issue, because many civil rights awards are not large, monetarily, and certainly some ask for injunctive relief.
So there would be no fee then, if you had a contingent fee contract.
Another question is, do I get, or does any attorney get less by having a contingent fee contract than he would be having no contract, nothing that said anything?
And that just doesn't seem the correct application of 1988.
The second issue in this is whether paraprofessional time should be included in 1988 fee, fee award.
It certainly is to be included, it seems to me, under the Loadstar calculation, and that is what I ask the Court to do.
It is to be included because if it is not the cost of legal services will substantially increase.

The work has to be done, the attorney has to do the work or have the work performed, so that the work performed by paraprofessionals, law clerks and paralegals, done under the supervision of an attorney, done subject to his responsibility and his malpractice insurance responsibility, seems to me absolutely valid to have that included--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You're going to add the secretarial time, paper, paper clips?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: --No, sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Electricity?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: No, sir.
And the reason why, Justice White, is this.
Part of it, I suppose, is tradition.
Never that I know about in my practice has secretarial time or the paper clip cost of overhead been included as a billable amount.
Also--

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Of course, in my day, we didn't charge for paralegals either.
And now apparently they do.
So maybe ten years hence paper clips will be charged for.

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: --Well, I, I don't want to use a crystal ball, Justice Blackmun, but--

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Anything to increase it.

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: --I might add that in, since I have been practicing, I do not know of any firm that does not charge a market rate to its clients of paralegals and law clerk time.
I do not know of any firm that simply accepts the expense of those services as simply overhead.
There's another reason.
Paraprofessionals are a profession.
They should be recognized as a profession.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What do you mean when you say they're a profession?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: Absolutely--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, I said what do you mean when you say they're a profession?
I didn't ask you if you would repeat yourself.

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: --They are trained, they have a course of study, they are certified.
The American Bar Association has a system of certification of many schools.
They are in the same area as, for example, emergency medical technician.
They require special training in order to perform their special duties.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But are their duties more akin to what a lawyer performs or more akin to what a secretary traditionally performed?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: My opinion is they are much more akin to what a lawyer performs than what a secretary performs.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you charge for Lexis and Westlaw?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: I think there is a... I don't personally have Lexis and Westlaw, but I think there usually is a charge for--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, in Louisiana do they usually charge for that as a separate item?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: --I think that is charged as a separate item, but I cannot address it because I haven't used that.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Actually, they're a paraprofession, aren't they, they're not really a profession?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: Paraprofession, I suppose, is correct.

They are certainly, Justice Scalia, I suppose that they are, in my opinion, and I've been involved in the paralegal area for more than ten years in helping to organize the Tulane program, and have taught in two schools, and I would say that they are much closer to a profession today certainly than would be a legal secretary.
And that's the reason I say to the Court, they should be recognized as such.
If it were not for their work, attorneys would have to do the work.
The contact with witnesses, the law clerk in my particular case accompanied me three days at trial and was a great help.
One of them did the first draft of the fee application and researched the law on it.
These are not areas that a legal secretary does.
These are areas that are much more akin to what a lawyer will have to do.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Now, is this a law clerk or a paralegal that you're talking about who drafted the first application for the fee?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: A law clerk.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Who had, who is in law school?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: Correct.
Both... there were two at various times, after one graduated he was followed by another.
But both of them were seniors at Tulane University law school.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well now, would you have had a paralegal possibly draft a fee application like that?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, my opinion is that, if at all possible, law students or law clerks should do the legal research and paralegals, legal assistants, should do the factual part.
Are paralegals trained to do legal research?
Yes, they are.
Have they had as much experience?
Have they had as much training as the, someone in law school who's a senior in law school?
No, they have not.

So in the way I approach this particular case, and the way I've used both, has simply been that the primary duty of research is the law clerk, the primary duty of the paraprofessional is the contact with the investigation, the witness contact, although that was also--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What does the, what does the paraprofessional do when they're contacting witnesses?
Do they go out and interview the witness?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: --Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: By themselves?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: Yes, sir.
I have had them do that.
As a matter of fact I've--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And Is that a fairly common thing for them to do?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: --It's common in my office, Mr. Chief Justice.
As I say, I've taught the legal interviewing course, and my paralegal on this particular case was one of my students.
So I had no question with, with that individual talking to witnesses.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: What if you asked your brother-in-law to go out?
He happened to be passing by that way and you asked him to talk to this witness, just to find out if this witness saw anything.

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: Is he a member of my staff, Justice Scalia?
Is he a hired member under my control and for whom I am responsible?

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Oh, well, you offer him 50 bucks if he'll do it.

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: I don't... I would not consider that a paraprofessional.
No, sir.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And that's, that's the line, you can't bill it because he's not a paraprofessional?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: I would say it is not the common practice.
Let me put it the other way.
It is the common practice of billing market rate for paralegals, legal assistants, and law clerks.
It is not the common practice, that I know about, to bill the rate purely of somebody you hire out as an investigator, as a subcontracted event.
That would be something that would have to be a cost but not a market rate bill, and that--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is all that in the record?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: --I'm sorry--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is that in the record?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: --I'm not--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What you've just said, that the custom of billing and all in New Orleans, is that in the record?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: --I think it is, Justice Marshall.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You think?
Didn't you try the case?

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: I tried the case, but whether or not that particular item is in the record, it is certainly in the briefs, but--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Then you should have used a paralegal.

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: --I would like to reserve the rest of the time at the end.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Very well, Mr. Rosen.
Mr. Guidry, we'll hear from you now.

section.heading: Argument of Edmond L. Guidry, III

turn.speaker: edmond_l_guidry_iii
turn.label: Mr. Edmond L. Guidry, III
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
The Fifth Circuit in this case properly decided to limit the recovery of attorney's fees to the amount which the Appellant had contracted with his attorney to receive.
Any recovery in excess of this amount, of this amount, would provide a windfall either to the Appellant or to his attorney.
The Civil Rights Attorney's Fees--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, are you, are you suggesting that if the fee is limited to $4,000 in this case, that it must come out of their damages?
Are you saying the Defendant doesn't have to pay any fee?

turn.speaker: edmond_l_guidry_iii
turn.label: Mr. Edmond L. Guidry, III
turn.text: --No.
I think that the Defendant does have to pay in addition $4,000 in attorney's fees.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And, so that the Plaintiff is coming out better than his contingent contract--

turn.speaker: edmond_l_guidry_iii
turn.label: Mr. Edmond L. Guidry, III
turn.text: Certainly.
His obligation to his attorney would be fulfilled by the Defendant's payment of attorney's fees and he would receive the entirety of his judgment.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --Yes.
All right.

turn.speaker: edmond_l_guidry_iii
turn.label: Mr. Edmond L. Guidry, III
turn.text: The Civil Rights--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But the contract didn't provide for that, did it?

turn.speaker: edmond_l_guidry_iii
turn.label: Mr. Edmond L. Guidry, III
turn.text: --I'm sorry?

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: The contract didn't provide for that, did it?

turn.speaker: edmond_l_guidry_iii
turn.label: Mr. Edmond L. Guidry, III
turn.text: The contract simply provided for attorney's fees and 40 percent of the amount of the recovery.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And the client was liable?

turn.speaker: edmond_l_guidry_iii
turn.label: Mr. Edmond L. Guidry, III
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: So we are going beyond the contingent fee contract in order to reach the result that you explained to Mr. Justice White?

turn.speaker: edmond_l_guidry_iii
turn.label: Mr. Edmond L. Guidry, III
turn.text: In fact you are not, because if the payment of attorney's fees under the statute, as the statute indicates, is made payable to the Plaintiff, then the Plaintiff simply under his attorney's fees contract would then turn over the funds, $4,000, to his attorney and his obligation would be completed.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But you're arguing that the court is limited and fixed by the terms of the contract.
In your answer to Mr. Justice White you've just indicated that you can go beyond the contract by at least the contract amount.

turn.speaker: edmond_l_guidry_iii
turn.label: Mr. Edmond L. Guidry, III
turn.text: The attorney's fees are set by, by the court, is what they are awarded.
They are merely limited by the contract because he had a contract providing for, for a proportion of the recovery.

The Civil Rights Attorney's Fees Award Act is a mechanism that was designed by Congress to provide representation in civil rights cases to less fortunate by shifting the burden of, the economic burden of prosecution from the victim to the violator.

Simply we must look here that what Congress intended to do, and their purpose in passing the Civil Rights Attorney's Fees Award Act, was to provide counsel for people who were less fortunate yet had their civil rights violated.
In this case, Mr. Blanchard was able to obtain counsel by signing a contingency fee contract for 40 percent of the recovery.
Congress' purpose was fulfilled.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why then should the Defendant have to pay anything?
If the Plaintiff was perfectly capable of getting a lawyer in the marketplace, on ordinary terms, the purpose of the statute isn't triggered at all.

turn.speaker: edmond_l_guidry_iii
turn.label: Mr. Edmond L. Guidry, III
turn.text: Because the statute provides that the court may award attorney's fees if a prevailing party is successful in a civil rights action.
While Congress fully intended to make the representation of the less fortunate attractive, they certainly did not intend to provide windfalls either to the plaintiffs or to their counsel.

A decision in this case not to allow a recovery in excess of the contract amount would not act as a disincentive in the future to attorneys handling civil rights cases under different contractual bases.

In a recent case decided by the Fifth Circuit in Hernandez versus Hill Country Telephone Cooperative, Inc., the Fifth Circuit approved a contingency fee agreement which was entered into between a counsel and his client where the attorney would receive 50 percent of the recovery if he was successful and no attorney's fees were awarded.
In the event that attorney's fees were awarded but less than 50 percent of the amount of the recovery, then the plaintiff would make up the difference in the attorney's fees.

If the plaintiff, if the plaintiff's counsel received attorney's fees in excess of 50 percent of the amount of the recovery, then the attorney would receive the court-awarded fees and the plaintiff would receive the entirely of his judgment.

Although the court was not excited about the percentage charged by the attorney, they said that the contract was not proscribred either by Johnson v. Georgia highway Express or other of that court's precedents and also that the attorney's fees agreement was not unreasonable.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Have you been involved in other litigation like this?
In 1983 cases?

turn.speaker: edmond_l_guidry_iii
turn.label: Mr. Edmond L. Guidry, III
turn.text: No, I have not, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I wondered that the practice was.
Are fees awarded paid to the plaintiff, or to his lawyer?

turn.speaker: edmond_l_guidry_iii
turn.label: Mr. Edmond L. Guidry, III
turn.text: In all of the research that I have done, I have not found any, any statutory or jurisprudence that indicates that it should be paid to one or the other.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, if the District Court says, the statute means what it says, I must award a reasonable attorney's fees to the plaintiff, and a reasonable attorney's fee in this case is $10,000, and he says, pay it to the plaintiff, and it's paid to the plaintiff, do you suppose the plaintiff could then say to his lawyer, sorry, I'm only going to pay you $4,000?

turn.speaker: edmond_l_guidry_iii
turn.label: Mr. Edmond L. Guidry, III
turn.text: I think that he could say that if he had a contingency fee contract that provided for an amount different than the amount awarded by the court.
And that's the problem in this case.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, that's this case too.
That's this case.
I would think you would be disagreeing then with the Court of Appeals, in a way.

turn.speaker: edmond_l_guidry_iii
turn.label: Mr. Edmond L. Guidry, III
turn.text: I think that's exactly what the Court of Appeals said in this case.
It was my understanding of the decision.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, your understanding then is in this case, when $7,500 was awarded, the client didn't just keep $4,000, he would keep the whole $7,500 and the lawyer would only get $4,000.

turn.speaker: edmond_l_guidry_iii
turn.label: Mr. Edmond L. Guidry, III
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So you two disagree on the meaning of this judgment, if it had just... it says the Plaintiff gets the money.
That's what the judgment says.
The Plaintiff shall recover the reasonable attorney's fee of $7,500.

turn.speaker: edmond_l_guidry_iii
turn.label: Mr. Edmond L. Guidry, III
turn.text: The judgment says that, the statute says the prevailing party, and then the legislative history to the Civil Rights Attorney's Fees Award Act, it indicates that, you know, if victims are to be able to pursue their civil rights, then they must be able to recover what it costs them to--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Of course, actually, I suppose if you read the contract literally, they'd be entitled to, the lawyer would be entitled to 40 percent of the excess, because the recovery included $10,000 plus $7,500, so his 40 percent ought to be on the total $17,500.

turn.speaker: edmond_l_guidry_iii
turn.label: Mr. Edmond L. Guidry, III
turn.text: --Depending on whether the contract includes recovery of attorney's fees also.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Whereupon you'd have to reopen the judgment to give that excess too, I, I assume.

turn.speaker: edmond_l_guidry_iii
turn.label: Mr. Edmond L. Guidry, III
turn.text: Certainly.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No, the judgment is for $17,500.
Put the two together and it's a matter of private contract, he has to pay his debt of 40 percent.

turn.speaker: edmond_l_guidry_iii
turn.label: Mr. Edmond L. Guidry, III
turn.text: That's correct... whether or not it would be covered by the contract I'm not certain.
By limiting the recovery of attorney's fees in this case neither the Appellant nor Congress' intent to foster the enforcement of civil rights is disserved.
The Appellant's obligation to the attorney is paid and he received a favorable judgment without any cost to himself.

The attorney may not accept another civil rights case under a contingency fee contract providing for a proportion of the damages, but it should not prevent him from handling other civil rights cases under different contractual bases.
The Fifth Circuit in Blanchard does not conflict with this Court's decision in City of Riverside v. Rivera, as had been claimed by the Appellant.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Excuse me.
Can I ask how your theory works to the case where there is no agreed contractual price?
Let's assume the law firm is a public interest law firm, it's provided its services for free.
You've just said that any reasonable attorney's fees awarded go to the plaintiff.
So I assume you would say that in that case, what, either no fees are awarded at all or else the plaintiff gets reasonable attorney's fees, and if he does he can keep them.

turn.speaker: edmond_l_guidry_iii
turn.label: Mr. Edmond L. Guidry, III
turn.text: I think--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And the lawyer never gets anything.

turn.speaker: edmond_l_guidry_iii
turn.label: Mr. Edmond L. Guidry, III
turn.text: --In the case of pro bono work and in the case of public service legal corporations, that Congress by approving the method of payment in Stanford Daly and in the Davis case, which was cited in the history--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Where did it prove that?

turn.speaker: edmond_l_guidry_iii
turn.label: Mr. Edmond L. Guidry, III
turn.text: --In the legislative history--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Oh.

turn.speaker: edmond_l_guidry_iii
turn.label: Mr. Edmond L. Guidry, III
turn.text: --To the Civil Rights Attorney's Fees Award Act, Congress cited those two cases as being cases where proper awards were made, one of which was to a, in pro bono work, the other was to a non-profit public service legal corporation.

And by approving both of those cases, we can assume that Congress intended that they receive attorney's fees for their work, even though they may be prevented from entering into a contract with the plaintiff to receive fees.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, that clear goes... once you concede that you concede the purpose of the act is, goes beyond making the plaintiff whole, once you concede that.
I mean, in that case you don't have to give the plaintiff a penny in order to make the plaintiff whole.

turn.speaker: edmond_l_guidry_iii
turn.label: Mr. Edmond L. Guidry, III
turn.text: Certainly you have to give, you have to make, to make the plaintiff whole you still have to provide these funds, because without these funds these public service corporations would not be able to represent plaintiff.
So in that respect it makes representation available to less fortunate citizens.

As the Fifth Circuit noted in its case, if plaintiffs such as Arthur Blanchard are able to obtain counsel to represent them under a contingency fee arrangement providing for payment of attorney's fees based on a proportion of the recovery, then in those cases the attorney cannot be said to have relied upon the statutory assurance that he would receive any other fee than that provided in the contract.

Certainly I can tell the Court that when a client comes into my office, before I accept the case on any fee basis, I know what the case is about, and I know what fee I will charge for a particular type case.
Certainly the more risky the case the larger the percentage of attorney's fees which would be charged.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But you don't always know, do you, Mr. Guidry, who all the possible defendants are until you do some investigation or have someone do some investigation for you?

turn.speaker: edmond_l_guidry_iii
turn.label: Mr. Edmond L. Guidry, III
turn.text: Certainly I think that is true, but you certainly know what you feel is the chance of, of being successful and what type of action you are faced with before you agree to accept the case.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, does one invariably know when a client walks in the door saying they've sustained some sort of injury, that this is a 1983 case or this is not a 1983 case?

turn.speaker: edmond_l_guidry_iii
turn.label: Mr. Edmond L. Guidry, III
turn.text: One may not know from the start whether or not it is a 1983 case, but you would not accept the case until you determined what type of case you were faced with.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You mean you wouldn't accept it until you could tell whether or not it was a 1983 case?

turn.speaker: edmond_l_guidry_iii
turn.label: Mr. Edmond L. Guidry, III
turn.text: I would not accept it unless I knew what type of case I was--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, what do you mean by, what do you mean by the words, "what type of case"?

turn.speaker: edmond_l_guidry_iii
turn.label: Mr. Edmond L. Guidry, III
turn.text: --Well, certainly they are, they are... I don't do any Sherman anti-trust work.

So if a client came into my office and presented me with facts which I was not sure what type of case, or what law I would be faced with, I would certainly research that prior to agreeing to accept the case.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But a lawyer who, say, specialized in plaintiff's personal injury work might not know just from the client's original recital whether or not there might be some sort of a public defendant that could be joined that would make it, in part, a 1983 case I would think.

turn.speaker: edmond_l_guidry_iii
turn.label: Mr. Edmond L. Guidry, III
turn.text: That may be true in other cases.
In this case I don't think that was true, because the facts of this case were that the Plaintiff alleged that his jaw was broken by an on-duty police officer in uniform.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, that seems pretty clear.

turn.speaker: edmond_l_guidry_iii
turn.label: Mr. Edmond L. Guidry, III
turn.text: Certainly to the extent that fee awards are intended to reflect fees charged in the marketplace for legal services, enforcement of the contract in this particular case is appropriate.
The Fifth Circuit held that the time billed by law clerks is necessarily included in the contingency fee contract.
The contract does not provide for the additional payment for legal support staff, whether it be law clerks or paralegals.
The attorney under the contingency fee contract is paid attorney's fees in the amount of 40 percent of the amount recovered.

There was no evidence presented at trial that there was any agreement to the contrary, or that there was any other provision of the contract which would require the payment of paralegals and law clerks, in addition to the contingency fee amount.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That's an easy question, if we agree with you that the agreed-upon contingency fee is the limit.
Obviously when a lawyer agrees on a contingency fee that's all he's supposed to get.

But suppose we disagree with you that that's a limit of the award, and we think you can, the court can give an award beyond the contractual limit, would you think the court could allow paralegal time in that award?

turn.speaker: edmond_l_guidry_iii
turn.label: Mr. Edmond L. Guidry, III
turn.text: I think that the court can award paralegal time in certain circumstances.
The case presented before this Court is that the... rather the decision of the Fifth Circuit is that the paralegal award is included within the contingency fee.
The District Court in this very case found that paralegal and law clerk time was not necessary, that the simplicity of this case prevented it.
So whether or not paralegal time, it may be recoverable under different circumstances is something that is not before the Court at this time.

Certainly if there was evidence presented at the trial that the cost of paralegals and law clerks is paid or billed to clients in that particular marketplace as an addition to the fee charged by the attorney, then I would say yes, it would be recoverable under 1988.

Any recovery of fees in excess of the amount contracted, including paralegal and law clerk time, would provide a windfall to the Plaintiff's attorney, in derogation of Congress' purpose in passing the Civil Rights Attorney's Fees Award Act.
The Fifth Circuit decision should be affirmed.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Guidry.
Mr. Rosen, you have three minutes remaining.

turn.speaker: william_w_rosen
turn.label: Mr. William W. Rosen
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice.
Let me try to put to rest the windfall argument.
If 1988 is correctly applied it cannot be a windfall.
They are mutually exclusive.
You can't have a reasonable fee which is a windfall, at least as I see it.

On the issue of what effect does the contingent fee contract have, the contingent fee amount in a contract may in fact be a reasonable fee, so that a court must look, may want to look at the contract, and the amount recovered, and may say that this is reasonable, and therefore one becomes the other.
But I suggest to the Court that it may not be reasonable, and it may be too, it may be too little or it may be too less.
And that is where 1988 comes into play.
The fee itself belongs to the attorney.
There's a 1934 Louisiana Supreme Court case on it, it was used in a 1982 Louisiana appellate case, in 1982.
As to the allegations that this, we all knew that an on-duty police officer broke my client's jaw.
The fact of the matter is that that wasn't known for some... the allegations were in the petition.

The question was, at the very beginning, whether this happened in a... he was in a bar room, he was not in a condition to know exactly who it was who hit him, as I understand it, at the very beginning, and therefore without some investigation that then led to the allegations that it did turn out in fact to be the on-duty, police officer.
As to the simplicity of the case, this is a case against basically the only law officer in this part of a rural Louisiana parish.
There was substantial fear that I found in contacting potential witnesses against testifying against this police officer.
I was faced by two very competent counsel, one for the bar and Mr. Guidry.
And this is not, I don't believe there's any civil rights case which are simple.
I use for the benefit of myself and my client, and in the long run for the benefit, as it turned out, for the Defendant the use of paralegals and law clerks.
Their time is compensable.
That is the system of keeping legal costs to a minimum.
They were very important in this case, and their time and their services should be compensated.
And they should be compensated, I suggest--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Rosen.
Your time has expired.
